qas.question: What still remains much shorter than intraframe compression?
What happens when a frame contains areas where nothing has moved?

answers.text: the system simply issues a short command

qas.question: What is a sequence that can be edited?
What still remains much shorter than video?

plausible_answers.text: the system simply issues a short command

qas.question: What happens when a frame contains areas that can be compared?
What is a sequence that can cause rotate?
What tells the decompressor to shift, rotate, or copy?

plausible_answers.text: the compressor emits a (slightly longer) command

qas.question: What happens if sections of the frame move in a powerful method?

context: The most powerful used method works by comparing each frame in the video with the previous one. If the frame contains areas where nothing has moved, <a1_0><b4_0>the system simply issues a short command<b4_0/><a1_0/> that copies that part of the previous frame, bit-for-bit, into the next one. If sections of the frame move in a simple manner, <b7_0>the compressor emits <b6_0>a (slightly longer) command<b7_0/><b6_0/> that tells the decompressor to shift, rotate, lighten, or darken the copy. This <a0_0><b3_0>longer command<b3_0/><a0_0/> still remains much shorter than intraframe compression. Interframe compression works well for programs that will simply be played back by the viewer, but can cause problems if the <a2_0><b5_0>video<b5_0/><a2_0/> sequence needs to be edited.
